This is a real disapointment. I dont understand why Eddie has to make this kind of pictures, is he on a contract that makes him do this kind of b-movies ? It was painful from the beginning to the end, i´m gonna forget about the movie as soon as i can. But i had to write it down, sorry.

reviews.review_title: Was surprised that I actually liked this movie.
reviews.content: I was surprised that I actually liked this movie. I think it started when Randy Quaid came out as the antiquated robot bodyguard. I know this movie flopped but it is definately worth a watch. The movie is witty, surprisingly action packed, and all and all a intresting story line that throws you for a loop at the end.

reviews.review_title: I was pleasantly surprised for ONE reason...
reviews.content: After hearing all of the negative buzz about this flick, I rented it myself because I just HAD to see how bad this was. And, while I admit that it's a definite bomb, I found myself enjoying it. Why is that? It's not 2001: A Space Travesty. That Leslie Nielsen vehicle is not only by far the worst sci-fi comedy ever conceived, but in the running for the most godawful movie ever created. If that movie were put into a time capsule for future generations to find, it would suggest a race of total jackasses. Pluto Nash, however, only suggests childish filmmakers, which is quite welcome after all of the heavy, serious fare we've seen lately. So to all of you knocking this movie because it's not funny, it's not interesting, or whatever, why not rent a copy of 2001: A Space Travesty? I guarantee you that Pluto Nash will feel like Gladiator after the unrelenting 90 minutes of hell that lie in wait for you. In this respect, I feel Pluto Nash has been unfairly criticized.

reviews.review_title: Shoot me if you must, but I liked the movie.
reviews.content: Ok, let's face it, it's not an Academy Award winner, but Pluto Nash was a fun movie (catchy theme music too).  I can't believe all the bashing this movie has taken, for a goofy fun movie...lighten up people and enjoy.  Pluto Nash may not be Gone with the Wind, but it's also not Dude Where's my Car :-)

I bought the movie, after not seeing it in movie theaters. I thought it would be nice to have a Eddie Murphy and a Sci-Fi flick in one, being that those are two of my favriote movie types. I was sort of disapointed. I mean for one, the cast did an ok job, nothing specail. There were some good scenes and side-stories, but rather few. I mean the main plot really sucked, and it was a waist of specail talented actors, if not for a few delightful scenes I won't spoil for you.In absolute terms, this movie has made the largest financial loss of any movie to date, with a budget of $100 million and a total US gross of $4.41 million (total loss, $95.59 million). Which is why it cost me so much to buy on VHS.Oh well...

Which came first Independence Day or The Adventures of Pluto Nash? Independence Day was released six years before Pluto Nash. The connection between the two? James Rebhorn appeared in both. Seeing him looking younger in Pluto Nash than he did in ID added to my sense that Pluto Nash was a late 80s or early 90s film. It just has that look and feel to it. Pluto Nash resembles 1986's Howard the Duck more than its 2002 brethren Star Wars Episode II, Lord of the Rings II, Spider Man, or MIB II (which also included Rosario Dawson). The reason that Pluto Nash seems out of place is that its genesis came in the mid-80s. For some reason, no one stuck a fork in it. Going into production 15 years (in 2000) after its conception is odd to say the least. The mid-80s were not the early 2000s. What might have been entertaining in 1985 wasn't so in 2002. The 80s were just a very different time. Pluto Nash has such an 80s feel to it that I distinctly remember watching it repeatedly on HBO while in my apartment. The thing is, I had moved from that apartment in 1988. Freaky false memory, huh? Other 80s features of Pluto Nash are its dialog, sets, coloration, and special effects. Cheesy is the word that describes the general feel of Pluto Nash. What perplexes me is that this movie cost about $125 million dollars. I could not see anything or any combination of things in Pluto Nash that should have added up to $125 million. A fifth of that? A fourth of that? Maybe. Maybe Eddie Murphy made a killing with his salary. Maybe Warner Brothers worked with the federales to funnel cash to the NSA, and Pluto Nash really cost only $1 million to make. The extra $124 million would buy a lot of flash drives.As cheesy and unbelievably expensive as this movie is, it is still moderately entertaining. Eddie Murphy (who hit his stride in the 80s and probably peaked just before this movie) is an entertainer through and through. I can't think of many roles where I haven't felt good from watching him work. (Delirious is one funny standup performance with him in that red leather jumpsuit and all.) Rosario Dawson spent a lot of the movie doing nothing but looking cute, and she excelled in that. (She's another performer who seldom disappoints.) Randy Quaid made a good performance as an outdated android. The part didn't have much depth or opportunities, but he scored some of the movie's best lines. All of the humor in Pluto Nash was subtle. Very subtle, but there nonetheless.Pluto Nash is a good movie to have on as background stimulus. Maybe at a family holiday gathering when the movie is secondary.

The problem with Pluto Nash wasn't if it is good or bad.   The problem (at least for the studio) is that this never was going to be a movie that could make $100 million, yet they green lit the spending for it.  Even with BOFFO worldwide and video sales, this will probably not even get within making half of their money back now.  One wonders what the producers were thinking, considering everything going against this movie:  1) Too goofy a title to be a summer blockbuster, 2) Eddie Murphy (other than Dr Doolittle & Nutty Professor movies) hasn't been a box office draw in 10 years), 3) I never saw a TV ad for this that I can recall, so, obviously the studio thought it wasn't even worth promoting once it got made.   This is really this summer "Anti-Fat Greek Wedding" (which was made for $5 million and will make $100 million, vs. the other way around).

reviews.review_title: I was surprised by how much I enjoyed this movie!
reviews.content:
Pluto Nash is not for the brainiac in us.I did find it an amusing and playful movie that I would recommend seeing.I read the reviews in the papers and on the web and I can tell you that the critics who get paid are wrong again. They seem to have gotten their noses bent out of joint by not being allowed to screen the movie before everyone else.For those of us writing reviews on the web, we seem to be a confused lot. Half of us like it and half don't. I went expecting a B grade Sci-Fi with cheesy Eddie Murphy jokes and enjoyed myself throughly. It's actually one of the better movies I've seen recently, believe it or not, mostly because it's not pretending to be something it's not, and then failing miserably.
I wouldn't recommend this one for the kids, not that there is much sex/violence, but more for the fact that the humour is just stuff that kids won't find funny. (I must be feeling my age. :)Don't go to this movie if you want great Sci-fi, don't go if you want great comedy, but I recommend it for those of you who just want to be entertained without a lot of thought!

Advance comments would have you believe this is some horridhybrid of Holy Man and 2001:A Space Travesty. It's actually a pleasant action movie with comic tones, sly touches and a nicetwist.. The trailer doesn't do it justice. I mainly went to see thepairing of Eddie Murphy and John Cleese, two comic geniuseswith different approaches.  I suppose if Jack Black was the star itwould be hailed as a comic masterpiece by those who thinkhearing the word "Malkovich" over and over again denotes genius. A good Saturday afternoon escapist feature and I did not hear the "Uranus" joke so take that to mean what you will.

reviews.review_title: Far better than most make out
reviews.content: Having seen watched this film last night, with a preconception of an all out dodgy sci-fi comedy I was pleasantly surprised to find that 'Pluto Nash' was actually a good movie. Much better than I originally expected and far better than some of these other reviews make out. The jokes aren't all that crude, the acting isn't too bad, and there are some good action sequences. The visual effects and sets are very good. Very Bladerunner/Total Recall in style. If you haven't got anything to do for about 90 minutes, I suggest going to see this enjoyable futuristic, comedy romp. It will have you laughing, for all the right reasons.

reviews.review_title: A Movie That Is Ahead Of Its Time.....
reviews.content: Feels like a simple case of "POLITICS AS USUAL",  when it comes to this movie.  Looks like the critics and the "REALLY SENSITIVE" took this flick way too personal,  because the only thing I see with this movie is teh "BALANCE OF POWER / CONTROL BASED ON ETHNICS".A good movie,  with an odd premise,  but funny just the same.  I would easily closely compare this one to the likes of "THE FIFTH ELEMENT, DEMOLITION MAN or TERMINATOR SERIES".All of these movies have rediculous, or unbelievable subject matter, but entertaining just the same.Timing also played a big part in this movie.  I truly believe that had this movie been released at the right time, it could have made all the difference.The entire cast and crew were GREAT!  I especially enjoyed the little things, (details that mattered),  which laced the entire movie together.The only thing I see here is that prevous movies Eddie Murphy starred seemed to shoot for a younger audience, where as this movie was set in the future,  it used a number of actors from an older age group.  (That is probably what attracted me).I guess if its all about the bottom line, ($$$ Cha-Ching $$$),  one must be more aware of the market they are targeting by using newer names (perhaps),  while also being aware who has the power or control in the movie.Its all good!  All about "Entertainmant"..... (Just a movie).  Some day there might become a time when our society, as a whole, can actually complete a movie that would meet or exceed the sensitivities of at least the majority of its viewers.;<)

This was a great movie.  I don't know why everyone gave it a harsh review. It had action and comedy, a perfect mix.  The robot was hilarious.  The jokes went great along the story.  A masterpiece waiting to be watch. 10/10.

Just watched this movie last night, interested in seeing how it turned out. I had heard from plenty of other folks that it was an enjoyable flick; they were right.  Everything about this movie is neat, including the acting, sound design, production quality, cinematography.  I think some folks just expected more, and were disappointed.  Usually I'm pretty critical about films, but this one worked well.  Is it another Godfather?  Not even close, but I give it 8/10.  And I'll watch it again.

reviews.review_title: They sure know how to bury a film.
reviews.content: Before this movie even came out it was buried.  But I thought a movie directed by a seasoned director like Ron Underwood, and starring Eddie Murphy couldn´t be all that bad, and it wasn´t. Someone put the word out, and it´s a shame. Eddie is in good form, and he has the capable Randy Quaid in a funny comedic role, and the film has some very good action sequences set to a pretty good score. I think Eddie is one of those special actors who if puut in most any film (except Harlem Nights, sorry) the film will be interesting. I think TAOPN was going to be a franchise film, and it´s too bad we didn´t get to see Eddie play this character again. 2.5 stars out of 4.

reviews.review_title: One Of My Favorite Fallback Movies Of All Time
reviews.content: I can not tell you how many times I have watched this movie! is it Eddie Murphy of old (when he had to prove himself?) No! (do you really think an actor should limit himself to what people want him to be?) Is it Eddie Murphy entertaining himself? well... it quite possibly could be! in any case, stop looking at his movies for what he used to be, and appreciate the man for what he is!! this movie was brilliant in a lot of different ways that simply are not "Eddie Murphy" I for one am glad he got rid of that old personification and made movies like this and Coming to America! (I think the world is much richer with them) and it's marvelous to watch an actor grow! (even if you don't think its what he should be growing into)

reviews.review_title: Not a great film, but not bad, either
reviews.content: I don't know why this film has been getting such bad buzz. It's the standard "wise-cracking protagonist on the run from the mob, trying to get to the bottom of things" plot, no more hackneyed than any number of other films which audiences have responded favorably to. It's got an amiable performance from Eddie Murphy, plus amusing support from Randy Quaid, Luis Guzman, and John Cleese. And, even though they're given little to do, it's good to see Peter Boyle, Burt Young and Pam Grier working. I though the cluttered design of the film, which reminded me a bit of Matt Groening's "Futurama", was well done, and I was pleasantly surprised that the design team and special effects team got most, but not all, of the sci-fi-geek details right (they still included an audible explosion in a vacuum). All in all, it's not a great movie, maybe not even a good one, but it's certainly not a bad one.

reviews.review_title: The sets, the goofiness, the lines, the story are all very good.
reviews.content: I watched this movie on TV on demand and thoroughly enjoyed it. Eddie Murphy, as usual, was excellent and the rest of the cast was just as good. I loved the sets, the goofiness, the lines, the story. Since I found myself wanting to re watch the movie I bought the DVD and the movie now stands on my shelf, next to my other favorites. Critics can be wrong. For example, back in the 1950s, "Imitation of Life", now recognized as a cinematographic masterpiece, was unanimously panned by the critics! This is just one example. Personally, I make it a point never to read them before watching a film. Instead, I check out the director, the cast and maybe the story. If I know neither director nor cast I use my own critical judgment based on the story, what my movie - savvy friends say and a general feel based on trailers. I might read the critics after seeing a film to see who I agree with or rather, who agrees with me. By unanimously panning The Adventures of Pluto Nash the critics have committed another Great Critic Blunder. The movie is really very good.

I saw this film in a second hand shop, and knowing that it had acquired poor reviews I wanted to see what constituted a 'bad film'. Well, the film has a very polished look about it. Although some of the moon scenes had a Total Recall look to them. The background artists were quite stilted and didn't look at all 'natural'. Back to the film. There was not much to the film. Characterisations were very simplistic, and the 'robots' were very curious in their presentation. It was quite a violent film, and what there was did not appear as comedic violence. One of the villains was especially ugly in a fashion which I suspect was comedic - cross eyes, curious gate etc. Murphy didn't add anything at all to a fairly limp script, and the Nash character was hard to pin down. There were a number of car chases 'on the moon', one featuring John Cleese, but any comedic angle to this went over my head. The end was very light - seeming to lack any sense of threat/urgency/difficult job well done etc. All in all, this was a poor film with what seemed high production costs but had neither any sense of originality, urgency or character empathy. All in all, it just seems boring.

Everyone complaining about this movie is a tool of the system, mouthing sound bites they heard somewhere else.  In fact, this movie is a lot better than many recent box office hits (incl. other Eddie Murphy movies).  I guess "moderately entertaining" ain't enough for H'wood when it costs 100 mil, but there are many, many examples more deserving of the stinkbomb rep PLUTO NASH got.  And most of them cost more.

Hrmmm, just about there worse movie ive ever seen... i dont have much to say about it, but i couldnt wait to get out of the cinemas, only reason i stayed till the end was because i was hoping somthing "interesting" and "good" might happen... but did it? no if you want a comedy dont see this.

reviews.review_title: Lunar Las Vegas With Fun Science Fiction
reviews.content: Fun theme music and some playful thoughts about life in the future (the Lunar Grand  Hotel, instant plastic surgery, the hillarious [sic] new face of money, and so on)  punctuate this action adventure. Pluto Nash (Eddie Murphy) is the owner of a nightclub  on the moon which has apparently been settled Las Vegas style by the time the movie  begins. His adventures occur as he goes about protecting his interests and his existence  from the underworld figures who are trying to muscle in on his turf. Dina Lake (Rosario  Dawson, also seen in Men In Black II) makes for an attractive cohort. Bruno (Randy  Quaid) is an unexpectedly sympathetic android character. Some will appreciate the  rather enjoyable exterior scenes of lunar habitats and Earthrise moonscapes. It's just a  movie, folks, but if you're in the right mood, it's entertaining.

reviews.review_title: I thought Pluto Nash was a great movie!
reviews.content: I honestly don't know why all these critic "SNOB'S" get listened to.? Judge the movie on your own! Let no one tell you how you should feel about The Adventures of Pluto Nash. I Honestly thought it was unique, light hearted, inventive, yes a bit silly, but SO what? It was a lot of fun and it had a very good ending. I think all of you out there giving this movie such a hard time need to stop taking yourselves entirely to seriously. Lighten up!:) I have read a lot of comments, and reviews on movies such as Megaforce. This movie was the same as Pluto Nash. fun, Unique, and after all is said and done light hearted. Like Puto Nash it had a great if a little over the top story line. You should look up some of the reviews. However I suggest you see the movie for yourself first. Remember It was made In what 1979-80? movie technology wasn't quite where it it today (except for the Lucas's and Spielburg's) of the world, but they did the best with what they had. I Just believe most of these movie critics are just venting their own frustration at having nothing better to do. So there being as mean as they possibly can.
The movie is fun and funny. Is it award winning no. But it's better than the ratings I've seen

Eddie Murphy is one of the best comedic actors but this movie is simply horrible! Hey gang! Have you been searching high and low for that movie that makes you don't care about the plot, the people in it or that you forget entirely ten seconds after the credits roll? If so, this is the movie for you! Watch only in extreme curiosity, or if you are into camp, which i barely think this is.
A classic crime drama about a nightclub owner being muscled out of business by a criminal gang with a sci-fi twist. What's not to like?
It's not so much a gag as it is a story, and it's not funny. It is almost almost a parody of Total Recall, which is also not funny.

Wow...This is one of the most soul less things I've ever seen. The acting is so naturally nonchalant its almost fascinating. There is way too much dialogue also. The jokes never got one laugh out of me. The cinematography is the definition of uninspired. Everything just blends in with a greyish metal and looks like every other Sci-Fi film since 1982. The special effects have a decent amount of practical effects and the CGI is dated but average. The music just like everything else is perfectly generic and forgettable. The editing is the most bizarre part of this. It feels like this is a Sci-Fi Film, A Noir Film & A Comedy all merged together. And the end result is a film that has no clear identity, tone or bite to it. half the time I can't tell whether the film is trying to be funny or serious. The pacing is oddly enough just ok. Never did I feel a scene went on too long (this is only a 1 Hour 30 minute film) but it never built tension or ramped up anything it just stayed at a perfectly consistent pace. This film can be summed up as if a computer was given millions of dollars to make a big budget film this is what it would present as the finished product. I've seen much much worse films than this. This isn't broken it just doesn't have any redeeming qualities to it. It's Not Good, I wouldn't even call it average its perfectly Below Average-Average. Skip this because the film clearly doesn't care so why should you.

Evolved scope that focused more on production values than storytelling efforts that are weak and childishly coerced, aimlessly looking for excuses to narrate around a neon playground being misstructured by disposable efforts, with only Eddie Murphy providing decency at his low bar minimum. (C-)

Now I know what you're thinking? This guy likes the Pluto Nash movie. And my answer is kinda. It's very colorful so you can't get bored with it visually. Eddie Murphy is great as always. Yes, Rosario Dawson doesn't have much to do in this movie besides eye candy which wasted her potential in this but that's the early 2000s for ya. The robot character was pretty cringe especially his annoying voice but at least had some comedic relief. But that kinda doesn't matter. We're all here for Eddie Murphy and he doesn't disappoint. He's saying the same funny jokes we like him doing and he's great. The story is kinda like a rip off high budget  version of Austin powers. But for some reason this movie really reminds me of scooby doo 2 because of the visuals and music. Maybe the same people did both movies. Who knows but I like that feeling. Anyway yes it's bad but it has a lot of stuff to offer. If you want a dumb fun movie this is it.

How can this movie have such bad reviews. It is FANTASTIC. How can you not like a movie that has Randy Quaid, Hottie Rosario Dawson, Joe Pantoliano, Peter Boyle, Burt Young, John Cleese, Illeana Douglas, Jay Mohr, Jacynthe Rene (can you get me..) and the beautiful Pam Grier. It is chock full of stars of various fame set on the moon. The criticism of the language and sexual content is absurd. It is one Eddie Murphy's least offensive films of all. Everything is well timed. Love that french maid. Lastly the comparison to the fifth element. I have to question whether the critic ever saw the 5th Element to say that.

At least the comparison to the Matrix with the chase scene in the tunnels is acceptable. Still, it is explainable and fits the movie rather than a copycat. Did I mention the french maid?
Then the criticism of Murphy himself. He may be vulgar and a bit brash at times but he always gave a great performance. Then the cast around him... they are great. This is one of Dennis Quaid's best films as corny as his character may be, it is memorable. 
Forget the critics reviews. Enjoy this movie for what it is, a fun romp on the moon. Sit back and enjoy Eddie Murphy in a completely alien environment from any other movie he has made. It is well worth your time.

Good watch, might watch again, and can recommend.

It's a little silly, but it's fine for an action comedy.  The only weird thing, really was setting on Luna.  Having on the its moon instead of on Terra didn't really add a lot to the movie except to facilitate a flimsy backstory and some scenes where people required environmental suits, and that had little payoff.

The benefits of being a sci-fi action comedy is to have laser effects for the blasters, and androids, which are used to various levels of humor.  

Eddie Murphy is great, and he plays well with Rosario Dawson, and if nothing else, you have to admit Randy Quaid is funny: the character would have been much different in someone else's hands.  I'll have to admit I thought it was Terry O'Quinn ("Lost": John Locke), which made even funnier at the time, but it's a good job done.

Honestly, Eddie Murphy and Rosario Dawson feel a little big for their roles, but the story is good: a former smuggler turns legitimate business owner has to find the mob boss behind the people trying to kill him.

While I do think this is an average movie, it is solid, and I don't think I would go changing a lot to it.  I could see a couple versions of a reboot, but in 2020, they'd probably put it in the MCU.

The acting is on another plane of existence, the set design is advanced and detailed, and the story itself is touching and fun for anyone. Ron Underwood's vision in the creation of this film...I'm tearing up just thinking about it. I can guarantee that this will be the greatest movie you ever watch. I wake up, Pluto Nash. I thought it was amazing!
This is one of the greatest movies that I have ever seen and I have seen it 234 times and counting, because I love it so much.
And the winner, of the worst movie ever in the history of Hollywood goes to: The Adventures of Pluto Nash!

Being one of the worse box office bombs ever isn't a good start really is it. Yet to look at the trailer, the sci-fi fantasy aspect and the films title you could be fooled into thinking this might not be too bad. The title is pretty sweet if you ask me, definitely an 80's movie title right there.

The plot is set in 2080 and mainly on the moon which is now called Little America. A location where gambling, girls, criminals and all things seedy are rampant, a bit like Las Vegas in the old days. Eddie Murphy is a retired smuggler who runs a nightclub on the moon and wants a quiet life, but this is all messed up when some goons come along and force Murphy out by destroying his club under the orders of a mysterious kingpin. Its now up to 'Pluto Nash' to find out why, who is the man behind it all and try to get his club back, or what's left of it.

I think the first issue with the film are the visuals. The film is oldish but not that old and unfortunately the CGI effects are pretty poor. Shots of the moon, moving vehicles, the lunar surface and of course Little America just look average and obviously CGI. When we close in on the urban areas the sets aren't too bad in design but again its terribly obvious its all sets. It all looks like a very mediocre attempt at a 'Blade Runner-esque' grimy neon lit urban district. The colour palette doesn't really help with everything being grey and boring, yes I know its the moon and the moon is typically grey but come on. There were some nice 50's-esque designs on some buildings and vehicles though, there was that element throughout the film but it still felt drab and lifeless, virtually black and white.

Then you have all the interior sets, design and costumes...its all grey!! everything is grey! flippin' eck!. Not only that but the interior designs look so dated, like its all been reused from a 60's TV sci-fi show. I understand that doesn't necessarily make it bad, there are plenty of examples where films have deliberately gone down the homage route or retro design/vibe which can work wonders giving a great charm factor. The problem here is the film had a massive budget and you wonder what they actually used it on.

Take the robot character played by Quaid (and the maid robot character). What they have done is simply apply a lot of makeup to Quaid to give him a doll-like appearance, then he merely acts out the robot role. Now again this can be done and it can work but probably best in low budget films that have little choice. In a big production it just tends to feel lackluster, the maid robot was the same but dressed up in a sexy French number as if that makes it more acceptable. I did quite like the 50's sci-fi sense I got from Quaid's robot though, like a butch Robbie the Robot in human form...kinda hehe.

Whilst watching I also found the plot to be a tad confusing really, or at least it didn't make much sense because it was all a muddle of grey. There are a lot of character names flying about here, a lot of seemingly pointless stuff, aimless boring dialog and not much action believe it or not. We just move from one cheap looking grey set to the next with little to laugh, disappointing seeing as its supposedly a Murphy sci-fi action romp.

But is it? you think it is but its not really, its more like a 1950's nightclub murder noir homage, 'Harlem Nights' in space perhaps. I must admit to thinking of 'Total Recall' at times whilst watching, it has that kind of vibe going on, minus all the excellent action and blood of course. Do I get the feeling this was made and acted the way it was on purpose?...was it?! I'm not sure, I'd like to think that but deep down I really doubt it. I just think it was a poorly executed movie which had potential to become a bit of a classic. I can see why people might enjoy bits of it like Quaid's cheesy robotic performance and the minor visual gags dotted throughout, but end of the day this really feels like its trying to achieve what 'The Adventures of Buckaroo Banzai' achieved.

I'm still not really sure whether or not this film was intentionally made like a low budget sci-fi B-movie for artistic reasons, or it just came out that way. The more I think about it, this might have worked much better as a short TV series, it certainly has the look and feel.

What a bad way to blow $100 million. This became a gigantic box office bomb for a reason. This movie never sounded interesting nor did it even look interesting. It was never funny, exciting, or appealing in any way. The script and characters were dull and lifeless in every way possible. There were many boring parts throughout that just had one-dimensional people and one note acting and bland dialogue that nobody will ever remember for longer than a week. I didn't even think they were trying to be funny most of the time because you are provided with lots of forgettable talk scenes and when the movie tries to bring you laughs, it fails and you are just sitting in your seat with a blank look on your face waiting for at least one decent joke to be presented. The consensus is exactly right when it says that Eddie Murphy was on autopilot because it seemed like he wasn't even trying to give a good performance here and he was going through the motions hoping that this film would be successful so he could receive a big paycheck and look what the results were in the end for this movie, this is difinitely one of his worst films ever. I however give the movie one star because I thought the effects in the movie were decent and the sets looked good, it's just everything else that brings the movie down on a lot of levels. 2002 had to be a rough year for him for also being in other disappointing films like Showtime and I Spy. After the film ended, it was as bland and dull as a summer movie could be.

The script creates situations where characters are shooting at each other and there should be some tension or at least excitement but you won't care about the characters and there aren't any big action setpieces that will get your blood pumping. The Adventures of Pluto Nash isn't the worst film ever made. It just might be the worst value for money though, with a reported budget topping 100M and a box-office of less than 5 it makes Jonah Hex look like a wise investment.
But despite this it is more sad than bad.

I can't possibly see where they thought the laughs were going to come from... I can't fathom which parts were supposed to be entertaining... Worst of all I can't really see where the money was spent...

I just sincerely hope it wasn't Randy Quaid's salary.

Pluto Nash was made by the same guy that made Tremors which is the inverse if Pluto Nash, a low budget / high entertainment affair that is remembered fondly by all that have seen it. Pluto Nash wants to be quirky, cool, edgy, funky and hip but is really none of these things.

It is 2080 and the Moon has been made hospitable for humans. Pluto Nash (Eddie Murphy) is the guy who everyone on Earth's satellite adores - except the bad guys who want to force him to sell his bumpin' club to them.

After a run in leaves his club a smouldering pile of rubble (like this film) Nash sets off with waitress Dana (Rosario Dawson - who obviously spent her paycheck on implants after filming ended) and his faithful robot Bruno (Randy Quaid).

The trio traverse the moon trying to lay low out of the gunsights of the bad guys while working towards finding who is ultimately responsible for their situation. Along the way they encounter many recognisable faces that add nothing to the film, Jay Mohr, Peter Boyle, Pam Grier, John Cleese and Alec Baldwin among others.

I think the aim was for Nash to be cool and likable, Dana the cute love interest and Bruno the comic relief.
All fail. As does everything else in the film.

But again Pluto Nash is as harmless as it is pointless, unlike the braincell shattering Tank Girl it made me want to sleep more than vomit - admittedly neither is an endorsement for the film - but the issue remains how could something cost so much look so ordinary?

Now I know how the Miami Heat must feel.

A big budget light comedy set on the moon and featuring its own fading star in Murphy was never going to be a big hit. This can't be the fault of director Ron Underwood but the big-wigs who greenlit it and opened the coffers. The absolute ceiling for this film was Demolition Man, itself decidedly average. The floor was Tank Girl, which Pluto managed to avoid but just barely.

Now you tell me; is a ONE HUNDRED MILLION DOLLAR investment worth making for a film that at best could end up mediocre?

Final Rating - 3.5 / 10. Pluto Nash sucks, but it is isn't the end of the world... unless you happened to be the one who covered the budget.

I actually enjoyed The Adventures of Pluto Nash.  It's nowhere near the disaster that critics and box office receipts would have you believe, in fact, it's a much better film than either Norbit or any of Murphy's live-action kiddie flicks.  What was it that worked for me?  Murphy wisely brings his leading man charm to the role, Rosario Dawson is an appealing leading lady and she shares a nice screen chemistry with her co-star.  I also loved Randy Quaid's bizarre yet tone perfect performance as Murphy's robotic bodyguard.  I had a lot of fun with this one.  Definitely look for this to develop a cult following.  SIDE NOTE: The score by John Powell is fantastic.  If you come across the bootleg promo album, definitely pick it up.

Eddie Murphy plays Pluto Nash, a nightclub owner on the moon who becomes Mafia enemy #1 when he refuses to sell his club so they can build a casino in it's place. He goes on the run with waitress/singer Rosario Dawson & robot bodyguard Randy Quaid.  Many fine talents are also on the cast list but each and every performance is just embarrassing. The effects look cheap and some of the sets look as though they were filmed in someone's garage.

Entry #3. [i]The Adventures of Pluto Nash[/i] (2002)
Director: Ron Underwood
 
Budget: $100,000,000
Gross: $4,411,102 - or 4.4% of the budget.
 
Now, finally, we have a movie on this Flops countdown of sorts that is just...boring....
 
Eddie Murphy, Rosario Dawson, Jay Mohr, and Randy Quaid all star in one of the most boring movies to possess a mildly interesting premise in the history of the world. Joe Pantoliano and an African-American albino fellow round out the cast. Nobody told any of them that they should try to be funny, apparently. Because they all just prove to be really, really boring.
 
The movie starts off interestingly enough. I forget how, though. After sitting through the entire thing, I don't remember too much of anything about the plot, or the characters, or the dialogue. Other than that it was bland, inoffensive, and not funny at all.
 
Pam Grier cameos as Pluto's mom. I think she's supposed to be funny. John Cleese and Luis Guzman come close to dimpling my cheeks, but every time the camera cuts to what I like to refer to as the 'enwhitened' Eddie Murphy - this passive, unconcerned feeling overtakes me. My eyes glaze over until Rosario shows back up. Although even she isn't that hot in this.
 
And who's the super-mega-evil crime lord boss keepin' Pluto down this whole time? It's not James Rebhorn - nope. It's Eddie Murphy as a Pluto Nash clone.
 
Yes. The villain is a clone of the protagonist. They fight, they're wearing the same thing, everyone's confused, someone asks Pluto a question only he would know - or something similar...
 
Everyone lives happily ever after in Pluto's new nightclub. The end. I'm literally about to fall asleep at work as I type this. This film redefines 'stultifying.' And this [b]still[/b] isn't worse than [i]The Stupids[/i]. Wow. 
 
I hate this movie. $100 million dollars could feed a lot of people, but instead, we get this. 
 
[b]1/10. An Absolute Crime Against Humanity[/b]. 
 
[u]Interesting Trivia?[/u] Not a whole lot. Let's see...
 
1. Eddie Murphy was paid 20 million dollars for this movie, which didn't even make back but a quarter of HIS SALARY.
2. [i]Starship Dave[/i] - coming soon to a theater near you. Eddie Murphy plays a human spacecraft. And nobody learned anything from this. 
 
Anyway, here's a list of the films to make less than 10% of their budget back that I haven't seen:

This is the largest bomb of Murphy's career (which, as you'll soon see, is saying something) and one of the biggest box office failures of all time. Written in 1985 and rewritten dozens of times by several writers, the movie sat on the shelf for two years after filming wrapped before finally offering itself to the public in 2002. It landed with a resounding thud. The production budget was more than $100 million. The movie grossed less than $5 million domestically. Ouch. The film has a terrific supporting cast, including Rosario Dawson, Peter Boyle, Pam Grier, John Cleese and Jay Mohr. The premise concerned Murphy's character searching the universe for the culprit who destroyed his intergalactic nightclub. A repeated joke in the trailer about Hillary Clinton's face being on American currency sealed the deal. Nothing about the film was funny and it was a terrible idea to begin with.

After watching this movie, I can see why it was a massive bomb. It wasn't because of the cheesy acting (which is standard for many of these Bruckheimer-inspired "blockbusters"), it wasn't because of the sci-fi theme, it wasn't anything actually about the movie. It was the premise. For some reason, I just don't really care about another night-club/theme-park/restaurant/gym/random-building owner who is getting bought out by the faceless conglomerate.
 
 The plot has been done a thousand times, and a thousand times better, but Pluto Nash came off to me as a sincere movie. I mean sincere, like they really put some thought and stayed up late nights to work out all those small details that make the movie worth watching. Pacing is also decent, with fresh action and situations keeping the movie moving. Static, cliched characters just add to that kind of cheesy vibe going through out the movie, which I wasn't sure whether it was purposeful camp or embarrasing seriousness.
 
 Either way, Pluto Nash is a cliched but acceptable little romp through space.

This movie is a futuristic movie about a man who is struggling to keep some guys from buying the club that he owns, which is the best on the planet...or umm..technically moon. 

Ron Underwood directed this HORRIBLE movie, which he has some good movies like Tremors and City Slickers and I won't go no further. Seeing no others were any good or I havent seen because they look stupid as this one did, but it was on HBO today and I was bored, so i watched it. Neil Cuthbert wrote the script, also he wrote Mystery Men, a movie that I think will suck but I do want to see. 

Eddie Murphy adds quite a bit of comedy but that doesnt help with the storyline, or any of the TERRIBLE ACTING. Eddie Murphys acting wasnt that great as he can be, he had good jokes but not the acting. Randy Quaid had a few good moments. Theres some pretty good actors in it like Jay Mohr, Joe Pantaliano, Alec Baldwin has a cameo. You got John Cleese, Luis Guzman. Altogether theres 4 hilarious comedians,but that didnt help out ANYTHING. 

You want a few laughs sure why not watch the movie, but the laughs arent worth it, they are limited. This is barely HBO materieal for when you're really bored. If you havent noticed I got 4 classifications I put my movies in: 1) Theatrical, 2) Rental, 3)HBO, 4)NEVER EVER WATCH THIS MOVIE (AKA-House of the Dead). Die-hard Eddie Murphy fans check it out, but his career is dropping, hes getting more of a kids person, like Dr. Dolittle, Daddy Day Care, The Haunted Mansion, which all were good except Haunted Mansion which I won't watch because it looks terrible. The amazing director Robert Rodriquez has targeted a few big stars to star in his next movie called 'Sin City' an adapatation of the graphic novel series by Frank Miller.
The cast he has in mind is: Leonard DiCaprio, Bruce Willis, Elijah Wood, Mickey Rourke, Brittany Murphy, Kate Bosworth and Jamie King. Some are signed on some are in talks and some just recieved the offer. Benicio Del Tory and Maria Belo's names are floating around as well. The film will film shortly, and will be about 3 intertwining vignettes revoling around a dark set of characters that call the fictional corrupt town home.

[center][b][font=Arial][size=6][color=sienna]THE ADVENTURES OF PLUTO NASH[/color][/size][/font][/b][/center]

 
[center][font=Arial][img]http://www.slightlywarped.com/movies/A/posters/adventuresofplutonash.jpg[/img][/font][/center]


[center][img]http://www.slightlywarped.com/movies/essays/2002/plutonash.jpg[/img][/center]
 
Every now and then, a movie comes along that tantalizes your senses, tickles your funnybone, and stays with you for the rest of your days. A movie that defines a generation and wins tons and tons of awards for its wit, its profoundness, and its heart.
 
The Adventures of Pluto Nash is not one of those movies. 
 
God, GOD! This movie sticks on ice. 
 
Eddie Murphy plays the title character, a man who owns a nightclub on the moon in the far future who is being pressured to sell his club to lunar gangsters so they can turn it into a casino. I guess its fitting that this movie takes place on the moon since both are so vacuous. 
 
This movie is about as fun as three months of math camp, about as funny as as watching a kid in a wheelchair get hit by a car, and if youre stupid enough to spend eight bucks to see this horrible thing, you should immediately loose your right to vote. 
 
Its just incomprehensible how a movie this bad could be made in the first place. I mean, didnt anyone see any red flags with this thing sometime during its development? 
 
Boy, this movie is rank. Comparing it to any other bad movie would be doing the other bad movie a severe injustice and I would probably get sued for libel if I did. 
 
Lets just say that The Adventures of Pluto Nash deserved to loose every penny of the 90 million it lost on its disastrous opening weekend. 
 
Ive got to stop going to these kind of movies just to see if theyre as bad as everyone says they are.

rt_summary: "Pluto Nash" is an action comedy set on the moon in the year 2087, starring Eddie Murphy as the title character, an audacious nightclub owner who finds himself in hot water when he refuses to sell his club to the local mob. The lunar gangsters are helping the mysterious Rex Crater mastermind a plan to take over the moon.
